channel.title: Alienware - Casual/Gaming laptop + connection question
channel.description:
Alright, first off, let me say this: I realize Alienware is a standard laptop with a fancy casing slapped on and an increased price tag. I don't care.
I've worked hard this summer and have managed to gather around $2,800. I want a personal laptop for gaming/casual use. My budget is around $1,000.
I'm looking at this: [url=http://www.dell.com/us/p/alienware-m11x-r2/pd?oc=dkcwat1&model_id=alienware-m11x-r2&]http://www.dell.com/us/p/alienware-m11x-r2/pd?oc=dkcwat1&model_id=alienware-m11x-r2&[/url]
A few questions:
I'm not majorly planning on using this laptop for gaming. Do I need to upgrade to a 500GB hard drive for $75 or will 320GB be enough for my needs?
The laptop does not come with a DVD/CD drive. I'm looking at the [i]Iomega SuperSlim DVD Portable Writer [$59.99 or $2.00/month][/i], but it says 'Alienware recommended for the [i]Dell External 12.7 Tray Super Multi Drive [$79.99 or $2.00/month] [/i](Although this might be a marketing technique)
Should I get the glare protector? Seems like a waste for $28 but if the screen will be damaged easily I should probably have one.
My connection question is this: I have a slow internet download/upload speed. How will this affect my actual gameplay? I realize my downloads for games will be extremely slow, but when I'm actually online, what will it be like?
I have a 60kb/sec download speed...what would it cost to upgrade to a better ISP for a decent connection? :P

item.title: Alienware - Casual/Gaming laptop + connection question
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

I’m not going to read this but all I have to say is I bought my laptop recently for €750 wich is $1080.

It’s Asus, and Asus is known for it’s great laptops, it has a NVIDIA Geforce 540M 1GB slapped in, it has a quad core i7 second gen, 750GB HDD, 6GB RAM, 17.3" led screen, numpad included in keyboard, a CD/DVD drive, aluminium casing,…

What I’m trying to say is would you rather get that ^ or that M11X peace of shit, what I’m trying trying to say is that, look for a decent laptop instead of going for an alienware.

This one let’s me play Crysis 2 with 1280 x 720 and high settings at 50fps, GTAIV 1600 x 900 everything maxed out 35fps, I mean, just look for a better laptop.

And if you can’t find one in the stores maybe order one from Europe, idk, I just bought this one in the store altough I got to say that I did not expect this laptop at all at that price, anything else with i7 started from €1000 so maybe I was just extremely lucky.

Read full topic

item.title: Alienware - Casual/Gaming laptop + connection question
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Out of 3 dell laptops and 3 hp laptops, dell have been my personal preference, don’t know why you have problems with drivers.
All 3 HP laptops run very hot and get to the stage where they can overheat so much that they shut down, 2 of which also had faulty ribbon cables for the monitors, which caused frequent flickering.
I’ve owned my dell studio 1749 for almost 2 years and it’s been brilliant, never had any problems, great value for money.

You’re gonna struggle to get something that’ll play the CoD games in high smoothly (mw1 up to black ops all require very similar graphical ‘power’), with a budget of $1000.

The GT540 card that was in the toshiba laptop mentioned here will be running black ops average of 40fps~ give or take in high settings, not the absolute max with AA turned on which’ll struggle along at around 25fps. You’ll be wanting 60+ fps for fast paced games like CoD so I suggest if you’ve got a bit of spare money then you opt in for something just a little more speedy, such as the GTX560M card. You’ll expect this to be running absolutely maxed at 65+ fps.

I’ve found that whatever laptop you buy, you’ll always be wanting more power in one or more hardware components, and the annoying thing is you can’t just upgrade, you’d have to buy the whole package again, so I’d just get the best you can, without being ridiculous, because you may be stuck with the same system for a while.

Read full topic

item.title: Alienware - Casual/Gaming laptop + connection question
item.dc:creator: @shrogg shrogg
item.description:
@shrogg wrote:

Jamie1200:

The thing with Dell is you pay for what you get, Quite literally. You cant add or remove components. Not from my past experiences anyway.

Yeah, my father brought a dell (against all my prior warning) and now he is conplaining about the graphics card not being good enough, and what do you know, in a rather new pc (08) there is no PCIe slot? wtfdellyoumustbetrolling

The last Dell I bought was a dell server I was testing out to see if it was worth buying 10-20 of them, it was the most upto date and it didn’t even have a ethernet driver preloaded, I had to load of the driver on a flash drive and install it manually. Then when I tried to return it 2 days later they black listed my calls and wont let me call again.[/quote]
Dell are rather shit, Oddly now Dell ads are plaguing the place

item.title: Alienware - Casual/Gaming laptop + connection question
item.dc:creator: @chassy13 Chassy13
item.description:
@chassy13 wrote:

How big of a difference is there between i3, i5, and i7 processors? I am customizing a Toshiba at the moment but for an i5 it’s +$100 and an i7 +$200. So how much of a difference is there?

The games I play will probably be games such as CoD. That type of graphics. I want it to look the best it can though. How do you know how good a graphics card is? By the ‘M’ number?

Thanks all for the help by the way, I don’t know a lot when purchasing computers.

Read full topic

item.description:
@R_A_R_E_S wrote:

[quote=“Chassy13, post:8, topic:412228”]I’m looking at Acer after I found a nice 1-star average based on 1.8k reviews for Alienware.

How would something like this be?: http://us.acer.com/ac/en/US/content/model/LX.RHQ02.021

Edit: This might be better, only difference as far as I can see is 2GB less RAM, very small battery difference and a 1.6" smaller screen.: http://us.acer.com/ac/en/US/content/model/LX.RGP02.036

I’m guessing ‘Maximum Memory’ is burstable RAM?

My question about connection still stands as well.[/quote]

I bought an Acer for about 300.00 and it has 500GB and 4G of RAM and Windows 7 I have no problems with it at all. Great for casual use and good enough to play games on sooooooooo I mean I’m not sure where you live or anything like that, but I got it for a good deal I think

item.title: Alienware - Casual/Gaming laptop + connection question
item.dc:creator: @Andrew_Ferguson The317Guy
item.description:
@Andrew_Ferguson wrote:

[quote=“Chassy13, post:13, topic:412228”]This is where I was basing my reviews for Alienware:
http://www.resellerratings.com/store/Alienware

Most of them are from 2010 so I don’t know if the quality has gone up or down at all since then…out of the 2011 reviews most are 1-star as well.

I’m really not sure what to think here, it seems everyone has their personal favorite and when they suggest one, it’s shot down by another person. :P[/quote]
I can’t speak for all brands really, but the reason that Alienware isn’t really a hot thing right now is because it’s company doesn’t want to upgrade their computers cause it will cost more so they just make it flashy when you can get a computer with the same specs for a few hundred less. Also don’t get a dell, they have horrible driver support. >>

Personally right now I think the best is gateway because they have the more advanced stuff like generation three memory cards, I’ve gotten two computers from them so far and I am now planning on upgrading my servers in my basement to one’s of their brand.
